query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Mentr’ io dubbiava per lo viso spento, 2 de la fulgida fiamma che lo spense 3 uscì un spiro che mi fece attento,
4 dicendo: «Intanto che tu ti risense 5 de la vista che haï in me consunta, 6 ben è che ragionando la compense.
query.result:
**English:**
1 While I was hesitating, with my sight extinguished, 2 from the radiant flame that extinguished it 3 came a breath that made me attentive,
4 saying: "While you are recovering 5 from the sight that you have lost in me, 6 it is good that you compensate for it by reasoning.
**Old English:**
1 Þa ic ðeah wæs on ðam dimman wudu, 2 of ðære beorhtan leoman ðe ðær bærnde, 3 com ðær an stefn ðe me spræc to,
4 cwæð: "Þenden ðu ðine gesihðe hæfst, 5 ðe ðu on me forlure, 6 ðonne is riht ðæt ðu ðæt mid ðinum ræde gebete.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Comincia dunque; e dì ove s’appunta 8 l’anima tua, e fa ragion che sia 9 la vista in te smarrita e non defunta:
10 perché la donna che per questa dia 11 regïon ti conduce, ha ne lo sguardo 12 la virtù ch’ebbe la man d’Anania».
query.result:
**English:**
7 Begin then; and tell where your soul is fixed, 8 and suppose that your sight is lost in you and not extinguished:
9 for the lady who leads you through this divine 10 region has in her gaze 11 the power that Ananias's hand had.
**Old English:**
7 Ongin ðu nu ða; and sege hwær ðin sawul bið gefæst, 8 and wena ðæt ðin gesiho bið on ðe forloren and na forworden:
9 forðæm ðe ðæt wif ðe ðe ðurh ðas godcundan 10 rice lædeð, hæfð on hire gesihoe 11 ða mihte ðe Ananias hand hæfde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Io dissi: «Al suo piacere e tosto e tardo 14 vegna remedio a li occhi, che fuor porte 15 quand’ ella entrò col foco ond’ io sempr’ ardo.
query.result:
**English:**
13 I said: "At his pleasure, soon or late, 14 let remedy come to the eyes that were blinded 15 when she entered with the fire with which I always burn.
**Old English:**
13 Ic cwæð: "Æt his willan, hraðe oððe læte, 14 cume ræd to ðam eagum ðe wæron ær forlorene, 15 ða ðe heo in eode mid ðam fyre ðe ic symle byrne."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Lo ben che fa contenta questa corte, 17 Alfa e O è di quanta scrittura 18 mi legge Amore o lievemente o forte».
query.result:
**English:**
16 The good that makes this court content, 17 Alpha and Omega is of every scripture 18 that Love reads to me, softly or forcefully.
**Old English:**
16 Þæt god ðæt ðisne hired gefylleð, 17 Alpha and O is æghwylcre gewritenes 18 ðe me Lufe ræt, ðe softe oððe ðe strange.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 E io: «Per filosofici argomenti 26 e per autorità che quinci scende 27 cotale amor convien che in me si ’mprenti:
28 ché ’l bene, in quanto ben, come s’intende, 29 così accende amore, e tanto maggio 30 quanto più di bontate in sé comprende.
query.result:
**English:**
25 And I: "Through philosophical arguments 26 and through authority that descends from here, 27 such love must be imprinted in me:
28 because the good, insofar as it is understood as good, 29 thus kindles love, and all the more 30 the more goodness it comprises in itself.
**Old English:**
25 And ic: "Þurh wisdomes wordum 26 and þurh anweald þe of heonon cymð, 27 swylc lufu gebyreð ðæt heo on me gewurðe:
28 forðæm ðe ðæt gode, swa swa hit god is, swa hit man ongiteð, 29 swa hit lufe onæleð, and swa mycel mare 30 swa hit mare godnesse on him selfum hæfð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Dunque a l’essenza ov’ è tanto avvantaggio, 32 che ciascun ben che fuor di lei si trova 33 altro non è ch’un lume di suo raggio,
34 più che in altra convien che si mova 35 la mente, amando, di ciascun che cerne 36 il vero in che si fonda questa prova.
query.result:
**English:**
31 Therefore, the essence in which there is so much advantage, 32 that every good which is found outside of it 33 is nothing but a ray of its light,
34 more than in any other thing, the mind of each person who discerns 35 the truth on which this proof is founded 36 must move, loving.
**Old English:**
31 Forðæm ðære andwlætan ðe ðær is swilce micel gesælð, 32 ðæt ælc gōd ðæt būtan hire is funden 33 nis nāht elles būton lēoht hire beorhto.
34 Māre ðonne on ōðerre ðing ðæt mód sceal 35 ðæs monnes ðe ðone sōð gesēoð 36 on ðære grundfeste ðe ðeos cūðnes on stent.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Tal vero a l’intelletto mïo sterne 38 colui che mi dimostra il primo amore 39 di tutte le sustanze sempiterne.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Such truth to my intellect my stars reveal, 38 he who shows me the first love 39 of all eternal substances.
**Old English:**
37 Swylc soðfæstnes mîn mód geseah 38 se ðe me ærest lufe lærde 39 ealra gesceafta ðara ðe sind.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 Sternel la voce del verace autore, 41 che dice a Moïsè, di sé parlando: 42 ‘Io ti farò vedere ogne valore’.
query.result:
**English:**
40 The voice of the true Author is silent, 41 who says to Moses, speaking of himself: 42 ‘I will show you every value’.
**Old English:**
40 ðæs soðfæstan Freond ða ða geswac, 41 se ðe Moyses ðus to him sprecende: 42 ‘Ic ðe ætiewan wille ælce mærðe’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Sternilmi tu ancora, incominciando 44 l’alto preconio che grida l’arcano 45 di qui là giù sovra ogne altro bando».
query.result:
**English:**
43 Spread out before me again, beginning 44 the lofty sermon that proclaims the mystery 45 from here below to every other edict».
**Old English:**
43 Astrecemeðu eft, onginnende 44 ðone heanlican bodscipe ðe bodað ðæt digle 45 of ðissum life ofer ealra ðinga gebann».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 E io udi’: «Per intelletto umano 47 e per autoritadi a lui concorde 48 d’i tuoi amori a Dio guarda il sovrano.
query.result:
**English:**
46 And I heard: "Through human intellect 47 and through authority that agrees with it, 48 look to the sovereign of your love for God.
**Old English:**
46 And ic gehyrde: "Þurh monnes geþoht 47 and þurh anweald him geþafiende 48 ðinra lufa to Gode lociað ðone hehstan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Ma dì ancor se tu senti altre corde 50 tirarti verso lui, sì che tu suone 51 con quanti denti questo amor ti morde».
query.result:
**English:**
49 But tell me, do you feel other strings 50 pulling you towards him, so that you sound 51 with all your teeth how much this love bites you?
**Old English:**
49 Ac secge me ðu ðeah ðæt ðu ða strengas fele 50 tihten ðe to him, swa ðæt ðu hlimme 51 mid eallum ðinum toðum ðæt ðeos lufe ðe biteð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Non fu latente la santa intenzione 53 de l’aguglia di Cristo, anzi m’accorsi 54 dove volea menar mia professione.
query.result:
**English:**
52 The holy intention of Christ's eagle was not hidden, 53 indeed I realized 54 where it wanted to lead my profession.
**Old English:**
52 Nis ðæs halgan ðæs Hælendes ðomas 53 digol ðurh ðæs Cristes earn, ac ic ðær oncneow 54 hwær ðu woldest ðæt min agen ðeaw wäre.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Però ricominciai: «Tutti quei morsi 56 che posson far lo cor volgere a Dio, 57 a la mia caritate son concorsi:
58 ché l’essere del mondo e l’esser mio, 59 la morte ch’el sostenne perch’ io viva, 60 e quel che spera ogne fedel com’ io,
61 con la predetta conoscenza viva, 62 tratto m’hanno del mar de l’amor torto, 63 e del diritto m’han posto a la riva.
query.result:
**English:**
55 Therefore I began again: "All those stings 56 that can turn the heart to God, 57 have concurred with my love:
58 for the existence of the world and my own existence, 59 the death that He suffered so that I might live, 60 and that which every faithful man hopes for, as I do,
61 with the aforesaid living knowledge, 62 have drawn me out of the sea of twisted love, 63 and have set me on the shore of the right way."
**Old English:**
55 Þærfore ic eft ongan: "Ealle ða wunda 56 ðe magon ðone hyge hweorfan to Gode, 57 to minum lufe synd geðylde:
58 forðæm ðæs weoroldes wæs and min wæs, 59 ðæs deað ðe he ðolode ðurh ðæt ic lifge, 60 and ðæt ðe ælc geleafful man hyht, swa ic do,
61 mid ðære foresædan cwicre gecnawnesse, 62 ða aleddon me of ðæs gedwolan sæ, 63 and on ðæs rihtan me gesetton ofer ða ea."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Le fronde onde s’infronda tutto l’orto 65 de l’ortolano etterno, am’ io cotanto 66 quanto da lui a lor di bene è porto».
query.result:
**English:**
64 The leaves with which the whole garden of 65 the eternal gardener is adorned, I love so much 66 as the good that is given to them by him.
**Old English:**
64 ða leaf ða ðe ðone eallne ortgeard 65 ðæs ecan wyrttruman afrefreð, ic ða lufode 66 swa ða ðing ðe him fram him sylfum becumað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Sì com’ io tacqui, un dolcissimo canto 68 risonò per lo cielo, e la mia donna 69 dicea con li altri: «Santo, santo, santo!».
query.result:
**English:**
67 As soon as I was silent, a most sweet song 68 resounded through the heavens, and my lady 69 said with the others: "Holy, holy, holy!"
**Old English:**
67 Swa swa ic ða geswac, ða wearð ðær sona 68 stefn hlude on heofonum, and min lafdi 69 cwæð mid ðam oðrum: "Halig, halig, halig!"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E come a lume acuto si disonna 71 per lo spirto visivo che ricorre 72 a lo splendor che va di gonna in gonna,
73 e lo svegliato ciò che vede aborre, 74 sì nescïa è la sùbita vigilia 75 fin che la stimativa non soccorre;
76 così de li occhi miei ogne quisquilia 77 fugò Beatrice col raggio d’i suoi, 78 che rifulgea da più di mille milia:
79 onde mei che dinanzi vidi poi; 80 e quasi stupefatto domandai 81 d’un quarto lume ch’io vidi tra noi.
query.result:
**English:**
70 And as with keen light one awakes 71 because of the visual spirit that runs 72 to the splendor that goes from garment to garment,
73 and the awakened one abhors what he sees, 74 so ignorant is the sudden waking 75 until the power of judgment comes to his aid;
76 thus from my eyes every trifle 77 Beatrice banished with the ray of hers, 78 which shone brighter than a thousand suns:
79 so that I saw more afterwards than before; 80 and almost stunned, I asked 81 about a fourth light that I saw among us.
**Old English:**
70 And swa swa ðurh scearpne leoman mon awæcð 71 ðurh ðone gesihðlican gæst ðe gæð 72 to ðam beorhtan ðe gæð of gegyrlan to gegyrlan,
73 and ðone awreccan ðæt ðe he gesihð him bið andsac, 74 swa ungewittig is ðæt hrade wæccende 75 oð ðæt ðæt smeagung him to fultume ne cume;
76 swa of minum eagum ælc wacigende ðing 77 Beatris aflymde mid ðæs hire leoman, 78 ðe beorhtra wæs ðonne ðusend sunnan:
79 ðurh ðæt ic ða mare ðonne ær geseah; 80 and swilce gedrefed ic ða ahsode 81 be feorðan leoman ðe ic ðær betweox us geseah.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 E la mia donna: «Dentro da quei rai 83 vagheggia il suo fattor l’anima prima 84 che la prima virtù creasse mai».
query.result:
**English:**
82 And my lady: "Within those rays 83 the soul gazes upon its maker, 84 before the first virtue ever created it."
**Old English:**
82 And min lafdi: "Binnon ðam raedum 83 wlited hire scyppend ða sawul aerest 84 ðe ða forma miht gesceop aefre."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Come la fronda che flette la cima 86 nel transito del vento, e poi si leva 87 per la propria virtù che la soblima,
88 fec’ io in tanto in quant’ ella diceva, 89 stupendo, e poi mi rifece sicuro 90 un disio di parlare ond’ ïo ardeva.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Like the branch that bends its top 86 in the passing of the wind, and then rises 87 by its own virtue that lifts it up,
88 so did I while she was speaking, 89 amazed, and then she made me confident again 90 with a desire to speak that burned within me.
**Old English:**
85 Swa swa ðæt leaf ðe on lyfte blaceð 86 on wudurofum, and eft gewiteð 87 ðurh his agenre mihte ðe hit up ahefð,
88 dyde ic ða ða heo ðus sæde, 89 forwundrod, and ða eft me geworhte 90 modes swa micel ðæt ic ða spræce.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 E cominciai: «O pomo che maturo 92 solo prodotto fosti, o padre antico 93 a cui ciascuna sposa è figlia e nuro,
94 divoto quanto posso a te supplìco 95 perché mi parli: tu vedi mia voglia, 96 e per udirti tosto non la dico».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I began: "O fruit that wast produced 92 mature alone, O ancient father 93 to whom each spouse is daughter and daughter-in-law,
94 as devoutly as I can I beseech thee 95 that thou wouldst speak to me: thou seest my desire, 96 and to hear thee I do not tell it."
**Old English:**
91 And ic ongan: "O æppel ðe anæled wære 92 ana ðinum anwalda, eald fæder, 93 ðe ælc wif bið dohtor and snoru,
94 ðe ic bidde swa ic mæg ðinum willan, 95 ðæt ðu me sprecan wille: ðu gesihst ðine willan, 96 and ic ðæt ne secge ðe ðurh ðæt ðu hit ðonne wite."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 Tu vuogli udir quant’ è che Dio mi puose 110 ne l’eccelso giardino, ove costei 111 a così lunga scala ti dispuose,
112 e quanto fu diletto a li occhi miei, 113 e la propria cagion del gran disdegno, 114 e l’idïoma ch’usai e che fei.
query.result:
**English:**
109 You want to hear how long it has been since God placed me 110 in the lofty garden, where this woman 111 set you on such a long journey,
112 and how delightful it was to my eyes, 113 and the real cause of the great disdain, 114 and the language that I used and that I made.
**Old English:**
109 ðu woldest gehyran hu lange hit is ðe God sette 110 on ðam heánlícan wyrtgearde, ðær ðeos cwén 111 ðe on ða swíðe langen stige gesette,
112 and hu mycel wæs ðara minra eagna wynn, 113 and ðæs miclan graman selfes gefylsta, 114 and ðæt geþeóde ðe ic brúcode and ðe ic worhte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Or, figluol mio, non il gustar del legno 116 fu per sé la cagion di tanto essilio, 117 ma solamente il trapassar del segno.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Now, my son, it was not the tasting of the tree 116 that was in itself the cause of such exile, 117 but only the overstepping of the boundary.
**Old English:**
115 Nu, min sunu, nis ðæs wæstmes wlite 116 ðurh hine sylfne ðæs wræclastes, 117 ac ðurh ðæs mæðels ofermæðe.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 La lingua ch’io parlai fu tutta spenta 125 innanzi che a l’ovra inconsummabile 126 fosse la gente di Nembròt attenta:
127 ché nullo effetto mai razïonabile, 128 per lo piacere uman che rinovella 129 seguendo il cielo, sempre fu durabile.
query.result:
**English:**
124 The language that I spoke was completely extinguished 125 before the people of Nimrod attempted 126 the unfinished work:
127 for no rational effect, 128 because of the human pleasure that is renewed 129 by following the heavens, was ever lasting.
**Old English:**
124 Se ðæt geðeode ðe ic spræc wæs eal forloren 125 ærðæm ðe ðæt unfullfremed weorc 126 ðara Nembroða leoda wære gefylled:
127 forðæm ðe nænig ðæs geðohtes wyrcung, 128 ðurh ðæs mannes willan ðe bið niwe, 129 ðurh ðæs heofones folgung, næfre ðurhwunode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Opera naturale è ch’uom favella; 131 ma così o così, natura lascia 132 poi fare a voi secondo che v’abbella.
query.result:
**English:**
130 It is natural for man to speak; 131 but whether well or ill, nature leaves 132 to you to do as pleases you.
**Old English:**
130 Nis hit ðæt gewunelic ðæt mon sprecan mæge; 131 ac swa swa swa, ðæt lætð ðe geworden 132 æfter ðinum willan swa ðe sylfum licað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 Nel monte che si leva più da l’onda, 140 fu’ io, con vita pura e disonesta, 141 da la prim’ ora a quella che seconda,
142 come ’l sol muta quadra, l’ora sesta».
query.result:
**English:**
139 On the mountain that rises highest from the waves, 140 I was, with life pure and dishonest, 141 from the first hour to that which is second,
142 as the sun changes quadrant, the sixth hour.
**Old English:**
139 On ðæm munte ðe ðone wæg hæfð hehst ofer ða yða, 140 wæs ic, mid life clænum and unclænum, 141 of ðære forman tide oð ða ðe is æfter,
142 swa swa se sunu wrixlð his setl, ða syxtan tide.
